Hard was the conflict 'twixt duty, and love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: This is mighty pretty romantick stuff! but you learn it out of your play books, and novels. Girls in my time, had other employments, we work'd at our needles, and kept ourselves from idle thoughts: before I was your age, I had finished with my own fingers, a compleat set of chairs, and a fire screen in tent stitch; four counterpanes, in Marsailles quilting; and the creed, and the ten commandments, in the hair of our family: it was framed, and glazed, and hung over the parlour chimney piece, and your grandfather was prouder of it, than of e'er a picture in his house. I never looked into a book, but when I said my prayers, except it was the compleat housewife, or the great family receipt book: whereas you are always at your studies: Ah! I never knew a woman come to good, that was fond of reading.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Well, pray madam, let me prevail on you to give me the key to let Mr. Eustace out, and I promise, I never will proceed a step farther in this business, with∣out your advice and approbation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Have not I told you already my resolution?—Where are my clogs and my bonnet? I'll go out to my brother in the fields; I'm a fool you know child, now let's see what the wits will think of themselves,—Don't hold me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: I'm not going;—I have thought of a way to be even with you, so you may do as you please.

Well, I thought it would come to this, I'll be shot if I didn't;—So here's a fine jobb—But what can they do to me;—They can't send me to jail for carrying a letter, seeing there was no treason in it; and how was I obligated to know my master did not allow of their meetings:—The worst they can do, is to turn me off, and I am sure the place is no such great pur∣chase;—indeed, I shall be sorry to leave Mrs. Rossetta, seeing as how matters are so near being brought to an end, betwixt us; but she and I may keep company all as one: and I finds Madge has been speaking with gaffer Broadwheels, the waggoner, about her carriage up to London; so that I have got rid of she, and I am sure I have reason to be main glad of it, for she led me a wearysome life;—But that's the way of them all.

LG.HEAD: AIR. XXXVI.
LG.L: A plague of those wenches, they make such a pother,
When once they have let'n a man have his will;
They're always a whining for something or other,
And cry he's unkind in his carriage:
What tho'f he speaks them ne'er so fairly
Still they keep teazing, teazing on:
You cannot persuade 'em:
'Till promise you've made 'em.
And after they've got it,
They tell you—add rot it!
Their character's blasted, they're ruin'd, undone;
And then, to be sure, sir,
There is but one cure, sir,
And all the discourse is of marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I am glad I had the precaution to bring this suit of cloaths in my bundle, though I hardly know myself in them again, they appear so strange, and feel so unwieldy. However, my gardener's jacket goes on no more.—I wonder this girl does not come (looking at his watch); perhaps she won't come—Why, then I'll go into the village, take a post- chaise, and depart with∣out any farther ceremony.

LG.HEAD: AIR XXXVII.
LG.L: How much superior beauty awes,
The coldest bosoms find;
But with resistless force it draws,
To sense and sweetness join'd.
The casket, where, to outward show,
The workman's art is seen,
Is doubly valu'd, when we know
It holds a gem within.

SP.P: Hark! she comes.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS and HAWTHORN.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Confusion! my father! What can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Tom, are not you a sad boy, Tom, to bring me a hundred and forty miles, here.—May I never
do an ill turn, but you deserve to have your head broke; and I have a good mind, partly.—What, sirrah, don't you think it worth your while to speak to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Forgive me, sir, I own I have been in a fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: In a fault! to run away from me because I was going to do you good.—May I never do an ill turn, master Hawthorn, if I did not pick out as fine a girl for him, partly, as any in England; and the rascal run away from me, and came here and turn'd gardener.—And pray what did you propose to yourself, Tom? I know you were always fond of Bottany, as they call it; did you intend to keep the trade going, and advertise fruit-trees and flowering-shrubs, to be had at Meadows's nursery?

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: No, sir William, I apprehend the young gentleman designed to lay by the profession; for he has quitted the habit already.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I am so astonished to see you here, sir, that I don't know what to say; but, I assure you, if you had not come, I should have returned home to you directly. Pray, sir, how did you find me out?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No matter, Tom, no matter; it was partly by accident, as a body may say; but what does that sig∣nify—tell me, boy, how stands your stomach towards matrimony? Do you think you could digest a wife now?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Pray, sir, don't mention it; I shall always behave myself as a dutiful son ought: I will never marry without your consent, and I hope you won't force me to do it against my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Is not this mighty provoking, master Haw∣thorn? Why, sirrah, did you ever see the lady I de∣signed for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir, I don't doubt the lady's merit; but, at present, I am not disposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Nay, but young gentleman, fair and softly, you should pay some respect to your father in this matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Respect, master Hawthorn! may I never do an ill turn, but he shall marry her, or I'll disinherit him! there's once. Look you, Tom, not to make any more words of the matter, I have brought the lady here with me, and I'll see you contracted before we part; or you shall delve and plant cucumbers as long as you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Have you brought the lady here, sir? I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why sorry? what, then you won't marry her? we'll see that; pray, master Hawthorn, conduct the fair one in.—Ay, sir, you may fret, and dance about, trot at the rate of fifteen miles an hour, if you please; but may I never do an ill turn, but I am resolved.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS, HAWTHORN, Young MEA∣DOWS, ROSSETTA.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Here is the lady, sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Come in, madam, but turn your face from him—he would not marry you because he had not seen you; but I'll let him know my choice shall be his, and he shall consent to marry you before he sees you, or not an acre of estate.—Pray, sir, walk this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir, I cannot help thinking your con∣duct a little extraordinary; but, since you urge me so closely, I must tell you my affections are engaged.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: How, Tom! how!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I was determined, sir, to have got the better of my inclination, and never have done a thing which I knew would be disagreeable to you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: And pray, sir, who are your affections en∣gaged to? let me know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: To a person, sir, whose rank and for∣tune may be no recommendations to her; but whose charms and accomplishments entitle her to a monarch. I am sorry, sir, it's impossible for me to comply with your commands, and I hope you will not be offended if I quit your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Not I, not in the least; go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir, I obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Now is your time, madam.

LG.HEAD: AIR XXXVIII.
LG.L: When we see a lover languish,
And his truth and honour prove,
Ah! how sweet to heal his anguish,
And repay him love for love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, Tom, will you go away from me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Perhaps, sir William, your son does not like the lady; and, if so, pray don't put a force upon his inclination.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: You need not have taken this method, sir, to let me see you were acquainted with my folly, whatever my inclinations are—.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, but Tom, suppose I give my consent to your marrying this young woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Your consent, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: Come, sir William, we have carried the jest far enough; I see your son is in a kind of embarrassment, and I don't wonder at it; but this letter, which I re∣ceived from him a few days before I left my father's house, will, I apprehend, expound the riddle.—He cannot be surprized that I ran away from a gentleman who expressed so much dislike to me; and what has happened since chance brought us together in masque∣rade, there is no occasion for me to inform him of.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: What is all this? pray don't make a jest of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: May I never do an ill turn, Tom, if it is not truth; this is my friend's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: Even so; 'tis very true indeed. In short, you have not been a more whimsical gentleman, than I have a gentlewoman; but you see we were designed for one another, 'tis plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I know not, madam, what I either hear or see, a thousand things are crowding on my imagina∣tion; while, like one just wakened from a dream, I doubt which is reality, which delusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well then, Tom, come into the air a bit, and recover yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Nay, dear sir, have a little patience; do yon give her to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Give her to you! ay, that I do, and my blessing into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Then, sir, I am the happiest man in the world. I enquire no farther; here I fix the utmost limits of my hopes and happiness.

LG.L: All I wish in her obtaining,
Fortune can no more impart;
Let my eyes, my thoughts explaining,
Speak the feelings of my heart.
Joy and pleasure never ceasing,
Love with length of years increasing.
Thus my heart and hand surrender,
Here my faith and truth I plight;
Constant still, and kind and tender,
May our flames burn ever bright.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Give you joy, sir; and you fair lady.—And, under favour, I'll salute you, too, if there's no fear of jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: But may I believe this?—Pr'ythee tell me, dear Rossetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: Step into the house and I'll tell you every thing.—I must intreat the good offices of Sir William, and Mr. Hawthorn, immediately; for I am in the utmost uneasiness about my poor friend Lucinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: I don't know, but I have reason to fear, I left her just now in very disagreeable circumstances, how∣ever, I hope, if there is any mischief fallen out between her father and her lover—

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: The music master, I thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
What is there a lover in the case, may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad, so I am; for we'll make a double wedding; and, by way of celebrating it, take a trip to London, to shew the brides some of the
pleasures of the town. And, master Hawthorn, you shall be of the party.—Come, children, go before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Thank you, sir William, I'll go into the house with you, and to church, to see the young folks married; but, as to London, I beg to be excused.

LG.HEAD: AIR XL.
LG.L: If ever I'm catch'd in those regions of smoak,
That seat of confusion and noise,
May I ne'er know the sweets of a slumber unbroke,
Nor the pleasures the country enjoys.
Nay, more, let them take me, to punish my sin,
Where, gaping, the Cockneys they fleece,
Clap me up with their monsters, cry, masters, walk in,
And shew me for two-pence a-piece.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Justice WOODCOCK, Mrs. DEBORAH WOOD∣COCK, LUCINDA, EUSTACE, HODGE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Why, brother, do you think I can hear or see, or make use of my senses? I tell you, I left that fellow locked up in her closet; and, while I have been with you, they have broke open the door, and got him out again.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Well, you hear what they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: I care not what they say; it's you encou∣rage them in their impudence.—Hark'e, hussey, will you face me down that I did not lock the fellow up?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Really, aunt, I don't know what you mean; when you talk intelligibly, I'll answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Seriously madam, this is carrying the jest a little too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: What then, I did not catch you together in her chamber, nor over-hear your design of going off to night, nor find the bundles packt up—

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Why aunt you rave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Brother, as I am a christian woman, she confessed the whole affair to me from first to last: and in this very place was down upon her marrow-bones, for half an hour together, to beg I would conceal it from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: What sirrah, would you brazen me too, take that (boxes him)

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: I wish you would keep your hands to your∣self, you strike me, because you have been telling his worship stories.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Why sister you are tipsey!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: I tipsey brother!—I—that never touch a drop of any thing strong from year's end to year's end; but now and then a little Annyseed water, when I have got the cholic.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Well, aunt, you have been complaining of the stomach-ach all day; and may have taken too powerful a doze of your cordial.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Come, come, I see well enough how it is, this is a lye of her own invention, to make herself appear wise: but you simpleton, did not you know I must find you out?

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE. X.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS, HAWTHORN, ROS∣SETTA Young, MEADOWS.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Bless me Sir! look who is yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Cocksbones, Jack, honest Jack, are you there.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Plague on't, this rencounter is unlucky—Sir William your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your servant again, and again, heartily your servant; may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad to meet you.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Pray Sir William, are you acquainted with this person?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, with Jack Eustace? why he's my kinsman; his mother and I are cousin-germans once removed, and Jack's a very worthy young fellow; may I never do an ill turn if I tell you a word of a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Well, but Sir William, let me tell you, you know nothing of the matter; this man is a music master; a thrummer of wire, and scraper of cat-gut, and teaches my daughter to sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What Jack Eustace a music master! no, no, I know him better.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: S'death, why should I attempt to carry on this absurd farce any longer?—What that gentleman tells you is very true, Sir; I am music master indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: You are not, you own it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P:
Nay, more Sir, I am as this lady has represented me, (pointing to Mrs. Deborah) your daughter's lover; whom with her own consent, I did intend to have carri∣ed off this night; but now that Sir William Meadows is
here, to tell you who, and what I am; I throw my∣self upon your generosity, from which I expect greater advantages, than I could reap from any imposition on your unsuspicious nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Well brother, what have you to say for yourself now? you have made a precious day's work of it! had my advice been taken: Oh I am ashamed of you, but you are a weak man and it can't be helpt; however you should let wiser heads direct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Dear papa, pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Ay, do Sir forgive her; my cousin Jack, will make her a good husband, I'll answer for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: Stand out of the way, and let me speak two or three words to his worship;—Come my dear Sir, though you refuse all the world, I am sure you can deny me nothing: love is a venial fault—You know what I mean.—Be reconciled to your daughter, I conjure you, by the memory of our past affections—What not a word!

LG.HEAD: AIR XLI.
LG.L: Go naughty man, I can't abide you;
Are then your vows so soon forgot?
Ah! now I see if I had tryed you;
What would have been my hopeful lot.
But hear I charge you—Make them happy;
Bless the fond pair, and crown their bliss:
Come be a dear good-natured pappy;
And I'll reward you with a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P:
Come turn out of the house; and be thankful my brother does not hang you, for he could
do it, he's a justice of peace;—turn out of the house I say:—

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Who gave you authority to turn him out of the house—he shall stay where he is,

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: He shan't marry my niece.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Shan't he? but I'll shew you the diffe∣rence now, I say he shall marry her, and what will you do about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: And you will give him your estate too, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Why I am sure he's a vagabond.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: I like him the better, I would have him a vagabond.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Brother brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Hawthorn.
SP.P: Come, come, madam all's very well, and I see my neighbour is what I always thought him, a man of sense and prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: May I never do an ill turn, but I say so too.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Here young fellow, take my daughter; and bless you both together; but hark you, no money till I dye; observe that.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Sir in giving me your daughter, you bestow upon me more than the whole world would be without her.

LG.L: The merchant whose vessel, the winds made their sport
At last thus arrives with his treasure in port;
His labour requited, his duty he pays;
His dangers are past, and his heart is at ease.
Were monarchs contending to make me a bride,
Undazzled I'd look on their splendour and pride;
Refused should their crowns, and their palaces be,
Contented to live in a cottage with thee.
On Earth, if there's ought of substantial delight,
'Tis sure when like us a fond couple unite;
When blessed in each other their struggles are o'er,
And pleasures are heighten'd by pains gone before.

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
SP.P: Dear Lucinda, if words could convey the trans∣ports of my heart upon this occasion—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Words are the tools of hypocrites, the preten∣ders to friendship; only let us resolve to preserve our esteem for each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Dear Jack, I little thought we should ever meet in such odd circumstances—but here has been the strangest business between this lady and me—

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: What then Mrs. Rossetta, are you turned false-hearted after all; will you marry Thomas the gar∣dener, and did I forsake Madge for this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ross.
Hodge.
SP.P: N—ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P:
Adds me Sir, here are some of your neigh∣bours
come to visit you, and I suppose, to make up the company of your statute ball; yonder's music too I see, shall we enjoy ourselves; if so give me your hand—

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Why here's my hand, and we will en∣joy ourselves, heaven bless you both children I say,—sister Deborah, you are a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: You are a fool brother, and mark my words—But I'll give myself no more trouble about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Fidlers strike up.

LG.HEAD: AIR. XLIII.
LG.L: Hence with cares complaints and frowning,
Welcome jollity and joy;
Ev'ry grief in pleasure drowning,
Mirth this happy night employ:
Let's to friendship do our duty;
Laugh and sing some good old strain,
Drink a health to love and beauty,
May they long in triumph reign.
